Many Californians will be getting needed relief in coming weeks - but it's nowhere near enough. Too many are still struggling to pay rent and put food on the table, and they need help - not a President who plays politics with their lives.California begins sending extra $900 to those unemployed due to COVID-19
California officials will mark the Labor Day holiday by sending a $900 supplemental unemployment benefit to jobless residents.
latimes.com

Robust paid leave policies reduce unemployment, increase equity in the labor force, and shrink the wage gap. That‚Äôs why I introduced a Paid Parental Leave plan last year in the 
@LACityCouncil
. Glad to see CA take this step for working families.Millions of Californians would be eligible for job-protected leave under plan approved by lawmakers
A bill would provide millions of employees who work for smaller businesses with 12 weeks of job protections while taking family leave.
latimes.com

Too many workers are forced to decide between their paycheck and public health. This program would ensure that all workers are able to stay home, no matter what work they do, their immigration status or their criminal record.LA City Council Commits $50 Million To Aid Workers Afflicted By COVID-19
Los Angeles City Council voted unanimously Tuesday to use $50 million of L.A.'s federal CARES Act funding to provide people with two weeks of pay if they are infected with COVID-19 and cannot work.
losangeles.cbslocal.com

What we need is a real eviction moratorium for the extent of the public health crisis. If it‚Äôs unsafe for kids to go to school, why is it safe to evict them?

Evictions & displacement spread COVID-19. #AB3088 does not do enough to keep Californians safe. 3/3

#AB3088 is not an eviction moratorium. In fact, it weakens many of the protections we already put in place in LA. Instead of having 12 months after the pandemic to repay rent, renters now have no later than March 31, 2022 to pay back missed rent. 2/3

Last night, the CA State Legislature passed #AB3088, an eviction bill to protect vulnerable renters impacted by COVID-19.

In an unprecedented crisis, I‚Äôm concerned this is nowhere near enough. 1/3

"Eviction is not a solution to landlords‚Äô fundamental problem of maintaining rental income. Rent relief is."

This is why I‚Äôve introduced legislation to cancel rental debt in LA. Congress should do the same.Opinion | The Rent Eats First, Even During a Pandemic
Threatening to turn families out of their homes during the coronavirus fight isn‚Äôt just morally suspect; it‚Äôs dangerous.
nytimes.com

@LByockHi Lila - Yes. Thank you for your support for housing. I remain as committed as ever to building housing & resources to help our unhoused neighbors. Learn more here:

We don‚Äôt have to live like this. We don‚Äôt have to choke our city with pollution. We definitely don‚Äôt all need to commute to an office each day.

I have spent years getting our City moving in a more sustainable and healthy way - it‚Äôs time to rethink how we move altogether.

The Physicians for Social Responsibility calculated that air pollution related illness costs LA roughly $22 billion a year.

It also costs us the health and lives of our City‚Äôs people, particularly in communities of color. This is unacceptable.

Today, I introduced a motion to rethink how we work & commute.
This legislation includes incentives for telecommuting& work from home for business, and a study on the costs of air pollution.

We can build a healthier LA, we just need to reimagine how we move and work.

We have learned a lot since the start of the Coronavirus pandemic.

One of them - LA can learn to live without air pollution and standstill traffic.

The U.S. is the global epicenter of the coronavirus pandemic. 

That could have been avoided, and countless lives could have been saved, if we had a President that was remotely competent.

- If you can‚Äôt pay rent bc of #COVID19 you can‚Äôt be evicted.

- You do NOT have to sign a repayment plan. 

- You do NOT have to prove hardship to a landlord.

- You DO have 12 mos. to repay rent.

LA is on track to meet its housing target set in 2013. But over 91% of that are luxury units.

Let's call this crisis what it is - an affordable housing crisis. Too many luxury units sit empty while everyone else is pushed to the margins. It's time to change how we build in LA.

My motion does three things to fix this:
 Instructs City Planning to identify Los Angeles' middle class.
 Creates new incentives that spur more housing for this population.
 Prioritizes affordable & moderate-income housing in the permitting process.

This chart from City Planning says it all. Over the last 5 years, our city brought online 73,387 units of high-income housing.

Meanwhile, only *430* units of moderate-income housing was built.

This is insane.

JUST IN: 
@LACityCouncil
 unanimously approved my Moderate-Income Housing motion, so LA can finally start building more of the housing we need.

Right now, the largest share of Angelenos get the smallest share of housing. We need to flip that math -> http://bit.ly/2MBETmb

Now a mom in California, Chhovy makes a point to connect her children with their Cambodian roots. 

‚ÄúI am very proud to be Cambodian. I want my kids to know who they are and where they come from.‚Äù #AAPI #HearMeRoar #APAHM

Chhovy Pich is a pop singer born in Tonle Bati, a farming village in Cambodia. During the Khmer Rogue, she was forced to leave her family behind, eventually immigrating to Long Beach with an adoptive father.

Singing was the bridge between her two lives.

These families deserve better. Our country deserves better. I can‚Äôt believe I even have to say this, but we must be absolutely clear: There we‚Äôre no merits to the internment of Japanese-Americans. It was 100% wrong.
Not to mention that, 73 years on, they must continue to hear debate over the merits of their wrongful imprisonment.

I was at a memorial dedication for one of these camps in LA a few months back. I met survivors and their children.

So much of their pain lives not just in the homes, businesses and years that they lost, but in the silence that followed. The lack of reckoning with this injustice.

But no matter who you are, you deserve care for your #mentalhealth and well-being. If you need someone to talk to immediately or know someone in crisis, you can call 1-800-273-8255 or visit https://suicidepreventionlifeline.org

Happy #WorldMentalHealthDay. Take care of each other out there.

Prop 2 is designed to specifically address mental health needs for the #homeless and frees up $2 billion for homeless prevention #housing for individuals with #mentalhealth needs. You can read more abt it here --> https://bit.ly/2Mc40O8

The most visible effect of ignoring #mentalhealth is sleeping on the street every night. Our #Homelessness crisis is very much affected by an unaddressed #mentalhealth crisis.

Fortunately, we have #Prop2 on the ballot this November.

We are lucky in #LosAngeles to have the 
@LACDMH
 providing resources & connecting people to mental #healthcare. You can find out abt those services here: https://dmh.lacounty.gov

But critical #mentalhealth needs are under-discussed and under-funded. And we all pay the price.
Today is #WorldMentalHealthDay - the perfect time to reclaim our mental & emotional health as key to our well-being, and to reignite a conversation on #mentalhealth in our communities.
